slides.title: Executive Summary
bullets: AI-native organizations treat AI as a core operating system, not a bolt-on tool
Leaders shift from approving work to designing systems: objectives, guardrails, and feedback loops
Orchestration becomes the differentiator: humans + agents + tools working in governed workflows
The 2026 workforce rewards operators of AI: roles that blend domain expertise with evaluation and automation
Winning playbook: platform foundation, reusable workflows, measurable outcomes, disciplined risk controls

slides.title: Definition: AI-Native
bullets: Work is expressed as workflows with clear inputs/outputs, tools, and tests
Knowledge is retrieved and grounded with traceability to sources
Quality is managed via evaluation: test sets, reviews, and monitoring
Security and compliance are designed in: PII, IP, access, and audit
People are trained to delegate safely and improve workflows continuously

slides.title: 2026: Why Now
slides.left:
Tech reality
• Multimodal models + tool use mature
• Lower cost per token + faster inference
• Enterprise retrieval (RAG) is standard
• Agent workflows normalize automation
• Private deployment options widen
slides.right:
Business reality
• Talent constraints increase
• Margin pressure forces productivity gains
• Customer expectations: instant and personalized
• Regulatory scrutiny increases (need auditability)
• Advantage shifts to execution speed

slides.title: Leadership Responsibilities
bullets: Set the AI thesis: where AI changes the value chain and what good looks like
Fund a productized AI platform (data, identity, tooling, evaluation, monitoring)
Define decision rights: what AI can do autonomously vs what requires approval
Model adoption: leaders use AI in their own workflows and share patterns
Treat risk as an engineering problem: controls, testing, and incident response

slides.title: Orchestration Layer (The New Middle)
slides.left:
Work orchestration
• Task decomposition + routing
• Human-in-the-loop checkpoints
• SOPs as workflows
• Continuous improvement via telemetry
• Budgeting: time, cost, and latency
slides.right:
Tech orchestration
• Model selection + fallback
• Retrieval + tool integrations
• Prompt/workflow versioning
• Evaluation gates in CI/CD
• Observability: logs, traces, safety metrics

slides.title: The AI Platform Stack
bullets: Identity + access: least privilege for humans and agents
Data foundation: governed sources, metadata, and retrieval-ready content
Workflow runtime: orchestrator, tool registry, and connectors
Quality layer: evaluation harness, human review queues, and monitoring
Safety layer: policy enforcement, red-teaming, and audit trails

slides.title: Roles That Grow (2026)
slides.left:
New / expanded roles
• AI Product Owner
• Workflow/Agent Engineer
• Model Risk & Compliance Lead
• AI Operations (AI-Ops)
• Data Steward / Knowledge Curator
slides.right:
How existing roles evolve
• Analysts: from reporting to decision systems
• Customer ops: from tickets to resolution flows
• Engineers: from code to systems + evaluation
• HR/L&D: from training to capability building
• Legal: from review to governance playbooks

slides.title: Manager as Orchestrator
bullets: Design workflows and interfaces between people and agents
Define acceptance tests and escalation paths for edge cases
Coach teams on delegation, verification, and responsible use
Measure outcomes (quality, cycle time, cost) and remove bottlenecks
Build psychological safety: experimentation with guardrails

slides.title: Reskilling Priorities
bullets: AI literacy: capabilities, limits, and failure modes
Workflow thinking: break work into steps with measurable outputs
Evaluation craft: write rubrics, create test sets, review systematically
Data judgment: source quality, bias, provenance, and privacy
Change leadership: adoption, incentives, and operating cadence

slides.title: Governance Without Killing Speed
bullets: Tiered risk: low/medium/high use-cases with pre-approved patterns
Documented prompts/workflows with versioning and ownership
Evidence-first outputs: citations, confidence signals, and trace logs
Incident playbook: rollback, containment, communication, and learning
Vendor/model management: SLAs, privacy, and lifecycle controls

slides.title: Metrics That Matter
bullets: Outcome cost: $/case resolved, $/proposal produced, $/decision supported
Cycle time and throughput: time-to-first-draft, time-to-resolution
Quality: defect rate, human override rate, customer satisfaction
Adoption: active users, workflows run, reuse rate of patterns
Risk: policy violations, data exposure incidents, audit findings

slides.title: 90-Day Launch Plan
slides.left:
Weeks 1-2: Align
• Pick 2-3 high-value workflows
• Define guardrails + data sources
• Stand up evaluation + review
• Set success metrics
slides.right:
Weeks 3-12: Build & Scale
• Ship v1 workflows into production
• Instrument telemetry + monitoring
• Expand tool integrations
• Create playbooks + training
• Plan next wave of workflows

slides.title: The AI-Native Advantage
slides.subtitle: Build systems that learn faster than competitors
